INTRODUCTION 1.1 Burkina Faso is a landlocked country, with its southern border more than 600 km from West African ports. Covering an area of 274,000 square kilometers, Burkina Faso lies entirely in the Sudano- Sahelian agroecological zone. With a GDP per capita of US$230 in 1995, Burkina ranks among the world's poorest nations. Agriculture is the dominant sector of the economy: it employs an estimated 80 percent of the population, generates more than 50 percent of the export earnings and contributes about 35 percent of GDP. Agriculture's share of GDP has, however, been gradually declining; for instance, in 1965 it was 53 percent. There is significant potential for agricultural growth in the range of agroecologies that support specialization in different crops and farming systems. The Government has realized the critical role of agriculture for the country's economic growth, food security and employment. 1.2 The population, estimated at 10 million in 1994, is growing at the rate of 2.8 percent per year. The population density on arable land is high, and most rural people are engaged in low-input, low- output agriculture on which their livelihood depends. The recently prepared Poverty Profile shows that the incidence of poverty is highest among agricultural households. Thus, improving performance of the agricultural sector is critical not only to fostering economic growth, but also to alleviating poverty. 1.3 Although Burkina Faso's agriculture has performed well during the past few years, its continuous improvement will be crucial and substantial investment will be needed to meet this challenge. In 1989 the Government requested IDA assistance in preparing an agricultural sector adjustment program to modernize and diversify agricultural production, promote food security at the national, provincial, and household levels, and improve natural resource management. Serious natural resource and environmental problems led the Government to prepare a project on natural resource management, the Environmental Management Project, which is supported by an IDA credit (Cr. 2229-BUR, 1991). It was followed by an agricultural sector adjustment credit and several investment operations (para 2.30). The proposed Second National Agricultural Services Development Project, which would be based on the work started under two earlier projects (the Agricultural Research Project and Agricultural Services Project), would benefit from the policy changes effected under the agricultural sector adjustment program and the projects supporting it. II. AGRICULTURAL SECTOR A. Background 2.1 Past performance. Despite difficult agroclimatic conditions, the growth of the agricultural sector has been quite satisfactory in the latter part of the 1980s. The longer-term trend (1965 - 86) shows a growth rate of 2.6 percent/year, which however was below the population growth rate of 2.8 percent. Agricultural production markedly deteriorated in the 1970s, when the annual growth rate was 1.3 percent, but between 1984 and 1989, agriculture grew at an average annual rate of more than 5 percent. Favorable rainfall in some recent years (despite irregularities in interseasonal distribution) has allowed

The country can be divided into four agroecological zones on the basis of climate, soils and socioeconomic factors: Sahel, Central Plateau, Southwest and East. The Sahel in the north is the driest region; its rainy season lasts two to three months a year, and average rainfall varies from less than 400 mm to 600 mm. The dominant activity is livestock rearing. The Central Plateau is the most densely populated zone. Average rainfall varies between 600 mm and 900 mm. Environmental degradation is a major concern in this zone. Although economic activities are concentrated on food production, the Central Plateau has experienced recurrent food deficits except in years of exceptionally high and well distributed rainfall. The Southwest zone, where average rainfall ranges from 800 mm to more than 1,200 mm, has the best agricultural potential. In an average year, it not only supplies its own needs for food crops but can also devote 15 percent to 30 percent of the cultivated area to cash crops, mainly cotton. Livestock activities are important for both the sedentary farmers (for animal draft power and income from animal sales) and transhumant herders. The Eastern Savanna is the least developed, and the least environmentally degraded area of the country. Average raminfall there ranges from 600 mm to 900 mm. 2.3 Use of arable land. Of the 9 million hectares of arable land, about 3.7 million hectares are cultivated each year. The average farm size is 4 hectares. Family size is the main determinant of farm size, because most work is done with handtools and little hired labor is used. Only about one fourth of the farns own draft animals or have equipment to use them. These are concentrated mainly in the cotton areas. Use of tractors or power tillers is negligible. 2.4 The major crops, covering 84 percent of the crop area, are: coarse-grain cereals (sorghum, millet and maize); other food crops, including rice (4 percent); and cash crops, mainly groundnuts, cowpea and cotton (12 percent). Most of the sugar cane is grown in a single estate in the Southwest on a few hundred hectares. As noted, agriculture can meet the country's need for staple food only in good rainfall years; increasing quantities of rice have been imported since the late 1970s. Maize is the cereal that has the best potential for increased production. Although cotton covers only 5 percent of the cultivated area, it plays a major role in the economy, accounting for about one half of the total export revenues and providing an important source of funds for the households in the areas where it is grown. Cotton area and production increased steadily from 1968 to 1991, when a record production level of 190,000 tons of seed cotton was reached. Unfavorable world market prices, overvaluation of CFAF and inadequate credit and marketing services caused a downturn in production between 1991 and 1994. The devaluation of CFAF in 1994 has provided farmers with better incentives to grow more cotton (its production in 1995 grew by 5.5 percent, but the estimation for 1996 is 36 percent) and other export crops, such as green beans grown in valley bottom lands in the beginning of the dry season, and Karit6 (Butyrospermum
 3 parkii), also known as sheatree. The latter, which has been grown for centuries on farmers' fields, provides valuable income for women, who extract butter from its nuts. Livestock, which accounts for more than 10 percent of total export earnings, is the second most important item of agricultural exports (mainly to the coastal countries). Fruits and vegetables have good development potential and are increasingly important for nutrition. They are presently grown in small areas only. 2.5 Sector constraints. Although the potential for accelerated growth in agriculture remains satisfactory, there also are problems. The growth of the sector is constrained particularly by five physical factors: inadequate and uneven rainfall, low quality of soils, population pressure on land, scarcity of groundwater resources, and imbalance between demand for fuelwood and the growth capacity of vegetation. Other problems include the traditional system of land tenure, inadequate marketing outlets, smallholders' weak purchasing power and the high cost of inputs, illiteracy, the traditional undervaluation of women's work and the difficulty women have in getting agricultural services. Additionally, less than 15 percent of smallholders have adopted new technology, and extension and research linkages are inadequate. In the long run, the sustainability of the sector depends mostly on increasing the productivity of smallholders rather than expanding the cultivated area. 2.6 Rainfall is low and irregular. The rainy season is short, lasting two to four months (depending on the part of the country). The coefficient for annual rainfall variation, increasing from south to north, ranges from 20 percent to 30 percent. Crop farming and pasture management are hazardous due to the large variation in intraseasonal rainfall distribution. In these conditions, risk management is key to farming and herding. Farmers, therefore, try to reduce risk by extending the cultivated area for crops and feeding area for cattle rather than by intensifying their use of land. Moreover, average rainfall has been declining since the early 1970s. Although there is no scientific evidence that this decline is a permanent trend rather than a cyclical phenomenon, a comparison of the isohyets shows that they have moved south about 200 kilometers between the 1950 - 1967 period and the 1968 - 1987 period. As a result, farmers and herders have become even more risk averse and less disposed to adopting high-input or labor- intensive technologies. 2.7 The soils in Burkina Faso are generally poor, and the structure is seriously depleted. In the Central Plateau, the reduced vegetation cover has allowed the soils to become exposed to water erosion (from runoff in the rainy season) and to wind erosion during the dry season. In addition, the soils throughout the country are deficient in phosphorus. Because the use of fallow periods for soil recovery is fast disappearing and because very little chemical fertilizer is used (less than 5 nutrient kg per hectare annually), the soils are being rapidly mined. 2.8 Population pressure on good land is severe. Of the total area of about 27 million hectares, only 9 million hectares are arable--less than one hectare per person. This is too low for adequate agricultural production, given the low-input technologies used. The pressure on land is most severe on the Central Plateau, where about one half of the entire population lives. The average population density is about 60 persons per square kilometer, and as high as 100 persons per square kilometer in some areas. In this part of the country, the practice of fallowing has almost completely disappeared. Because the population has exceeded the carrying capacity of the land, spontaneous migration to the Southwest has taken place since the 1980s. There, the population density had been much lower because of onchocerciasis (river blindness), a disease that has now been eradicated by concerted international action. Irrigation is little developed; although the irrigated surface has doubled since 1982, it still accounts for only I percent of total cultivated area. The river systems have a short flooding period and become dry soon after the rains stop. Surface water resources, including permanent and temporary watercourses, are difficult to tap because of the country's flat topography. To have year-round surface-water irrigation under these conditions would require large water reservoirs and thus large investments. There is also evidence that the underground water table is falling as a result of lesser infiltration and higher runoff induced by deforestation. Fetching of water is becoming increasingly time-consuming--this chore usually falls on women and children--taking a large share of time from other agricultural activities. 2.10 There is a severe imbalance between the demand for wood and the regenerative capacity of the vegetation. About 96 percent of all energy used by households, including urban households, is derived from fuelwood collected from the dwindling forests and bush fallow. The imbalance is so severe that farmers are forced to burn crop residues and cattle dung instead of recycling them to maintain soil fertility. 2.11 Livestock sector. The most important constraints to the sedentary crop-livestock farmers is the poor quality feed, especially in the dry season. For the pastoralists in the transhumant system, the encroachment of cropping into formerly critical dry-season grazing areas undermines the entire sustainability of the transhumant pastoralist system. Diseases and lack of financial management experience of the commercial producers are major impediments to intensive pigs and poultry production. In livestock research, the socio-economic effect of the technologies being developed has not been assessed. In livestock extension, front-line staff suffers from lack of training in livestock technology and appropriate tools to demonstrate such improved. The current system is not adequately equipped to supply the specialized information needs of the pastoral and commercial sectors. For the veterinary services, inadequate sanitary control and poor diagnostic support facilities, and for the private veterinarians the lack of enabling environment are key constraints. The project would address these constraints. B. Agricultural Organizations and Agencies 2.12 Agricultural research. The Ministry of Secondary and Higher Education and Scientific Research (MESSRS) oversees research activities, but guidance, coordination, planning, monitoring and evaluation of research activities are provided by the National Center for Scientific and Technological Research (CRNST) and its Board of Governors. The actual research work is carried out by several specialized research institutes. Among them, the Agricultural Research Institute (INERA) and the Research Institute for Tropical Biology and Ecology (IRBET) are responsible for research in the agricultural sector. The forestry program of ex-IRBET has been merged into INERA to form a new institute, the Institut National de l'Environnement et des Rescherches Agricoles (INERA). The new institute will collaborate with the Research Institute for Applied Sciences and Technology (IRSAT) which is also based on two earlier institutes. 2Two of IRSAT's research programs, agroprocessing and agricultural mechanization, are of interest to the present project. IRSATs organizational and physical structure would be developed under the Second National Agricultural Services Development Project (NASDP II). 2.13 Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources. The Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources (AGRI-RA) has been in charge of the sectoral policy and overall development of the agricultural sector since 1986, when the water and rural affairs were divided into two ministries. Matters relating to cooperatives and other rural institutions were later transferred back to AGRI-RA. AGRI-RA has 12 Directorates, most of which will be involved in the implementation of NASDP II. The primary Directorates benefiting from the project would be the Directorate for Studies and Planning (DEP), in charge of studies, planning, monitoring and evaluation of projects and agricultural statistics; the Directorate of Agricultural Extension (DVA), responsible for extension dealing with crops, livestock and the transformation of agricultural products the Directorates of Animal Industries (DPIA), responsible for both the modern and traditional (pastoral) livestock sector; the Directorate for Veterinary Services (DSV), dealing with the animal health delivery including the public health aspects of animal products; and the Directorate for Promoting Cooperatives and Rural Legislation. 2.14 AGRI-RA is the main institution for planning agricultural and livestock production, providing extension services to crop farmers and livestock producers; training agricultural and livestock technicians; and carrying out adaptive research in the PAPEMs (Points d'Appui de Prevulgarisation et d'Experimentation Multi-locale) planned by and implemented in collaboration with researchers of INERA (Institut de l'Environnement et des Recherches Agricoles). Input distribution (including improved seed, veterinary drugs and supplies, and agricultural chemicals) and the distribution of credit also have been AGRI-RA's responsibilities. However, these two activities have recently been suspended. These support services have been provided in practice by AGRI-RA's 12 Centres Regionaux de Promotion Agro-Pastorale (CRPA), established in 1988 as successors to regional rural development authorities (Organismes Regionaux de Developpement, ORD). The main activities of the CRPAs have involved extension, monitoring, evaluation, support services and rural works. More recently, they have also advised on the promotion of farmer institutions. CRPAs have provided their centralized services to the three specialized units of the Ministry in each of the 30 Provinces (Service Provincial de l'Agriculture--SPA; Service Provincial des Ressources Animales--SPRA; Service Provincial de l'Organisation et de la Formation Professionnelle des Producteurs--SPOFPP). The level below the provinces is the zones, where the village level agents also have their postings. Since AGRI-RA's reorganization in 1997, the CRPAs have been replaced by the "Directions Regionales de l'Agriculture et des Ressources Animales" (DRARAs). They are public agencies with no commercial operations, which concentrate on the public services previously performed by the CRPAs (para 2.17). 2.15 Livestock Sector. AGRI-RA has overall responsibility for the development of the livestock sector. At the national level, it has carried out this responsibility through: (a) the Directorate for Animal Production and Livestock Industries (DPIA), which is responsible for livestock extension and the promotion of the modem production systems; (b) the Directorate of Animal Health (DSA), responsible for veterinary protection and quality control of food of animal origin; and (c) the Directorate of Traditional Livestock Production (DOET), responsible for herder organizations, including the development of special "pastoral zones." All three Directorates contribute to the training of the field extension agents. In addition, there are a number of semiautonomous institutions in the sector. The National Livestock Laboratory (LNE) and the National Distributor of Veterinary Pharmaceuticals (ONAVET, to be privatized soon) are the most important of them. In the 1997 reorganization of AGRI-
 6 RA, the Service of Pastoral Area Promotion (SAEP) has replaced DOET and integrated with DPIA. The Directorate of Veterinary Services (DVS) has replaced DSA. 2.16 At the regional level, livestock services are integrated with a Provincial Service (SPRA) which implements the animal health programs and trains the extension agents at zone and village levels. These three Directorates and agencies in the field involved in animal health and livestock extension have a total staff of about 40 veterinarians, 70 livestock technicians and 250 field agents. This gives a ratio of about one professional per 75,000 TLU (Tropical Livestock Unit), and 30,000 TLU per middle level staff, which is not excessive. Since 1991, when recruitment by the public sector stopped, an active private veterinary sector has developed. More than 50 veterinarians now operate privately (more than the number of veterinarians employed in the public sector), covering a substantial part of the Burkina livestock population. 2.17 Reorganization of AGRI-RA. During the process of preparing the Second National Agricultural Adjustment Program (PASA II), an extensive plan to reorganize AGRI-RA has also been promoted. With assistance from FAO, the Government has advanced, through a thorough process of planning and participation by concerned and interested parties, to a level where implementation of the new organigram and setting in place the other necessary changes were started in the beginning of 1997. The objectives of the reorganizations program are to: (a) assure greater efficiency of the public sector activities in the sector; (b) increase autonomy and improve professionalism of the economically-oriented farmer organizations and facilitate their participation in the planning and evaluation of public services; and (c) provide an enabling environment for the private sector to contribute to agricultural development more than hitherto. The measures to achieve these objectives are several, including introduction of a new organigram, detailed job descriptions and decentralization of staff and functions; reduction of staff in the ministry (para 4.4); liquidation of the loss-making commercial activities of the CRPAs and providing only purely public services through these regional bodies; and promotion of farmer organizations and encouraging them to take over some of the activities earlier performed by CRPAs. 2.18 Farmer organizations. There are more than 10,000 registered farmer organizations and groups (250 cooperatives and 10,627 precooperatives), in addition to groups that have been formed informally, for example, for agricultural extension and other purposes. However, the horizontal and vertical structures of farner organizations, common in more developed countries, have yet to be developed. Over the years, farmer organizations and groups have been formed following different promotion and investment programs supported by the Government, international assistance agencies and local and international nongovernmental organizations (NGOs). To facilitate centralized services and broader than local-level representation, some of these initiatives have led to the development of a vertical organization for some cooperative and other farmer organizations and to some expansion of the horizontal network of groups supported by the various initiatives. Examples of the national and provincial organizations are the Federation of Naam groups, Cooperative Union for Vegetable Growers (UCOBAM) and Federation Wendyam. However, these organizations and groups may not reflect real indigenous membership dynamism, but rather the policies and programs of external forces or groups with religious and political aspirations. 2.19 Nevertheless, although still relatively fragmented and uneven, the network of cooperatives and other farmer groups forms a basis on which genuine participatory development can be built. The Government has declared a policy of disengagement of the state from cooperative management and control, and empowerment of the producers as one of its main tenets of agricultural development. This policy is expected to be the cornerstone of the Government's approach and a condition of the donor community's support to facilitate accelerated development. This means that the Government and donors
 7 would: (a) help create a regulatory environment (including suitable laws and regulations) that promote self-help activities; and (b) would supply the new or growing organizations with what they need for successful expansion. The assistance to be provided under this project (para 4.16) is based on this policy. 2.20 Liaisons. The Ministries implementing the project (AGRI-RA and MESSRS) plan to maintain liaison with several other ministries to coordinate the project activities with other operations taking place in the rural sector. The ministries involved are the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Economy, Finance and Planning, Ministry of Water Resources, and Ministry of Basic Education and Mass Literacy. 2.21 Numerous other agencies are concerned with agricultural production, including the Societ6 des Fibres et des Textiles (SOFITEX) for cotton, the Caisse Nationale du Credit Agricole (CNCA) for medium-term credit, the S6cretariat Permanent de Coordination de la Politique Cerealiere for cereal production and the Secretariat Permanent de Coordination de la Politique de la Developpement de l'Elevage for livestock. Development and Agricultural Policies and Sector Development Strategy 2.22 Development and agricultural sector policies and objectives. Agriculture is the mainstay of the economy. Since the early 1 980s, the Government has followed a policy of agricultural development that aims at achieving food security, improving the incomes of the rural population, and protecting the environment. In 1985 the country endorsed the goals of intensification and diversification of agricultural production and improved management of natural resources and the performance of agricultural research. These goals were followed up by special programs for agricultural extension, research and community- based land management (Gestion des Terroirs). 2.23 Beginning in 1985, the development strategies for agricultural research were implemented on the basis of a policy paper titled "Lignes Directrices d'Organisation et d'Administration Strategique de Recherches Agricoles." It emphasized agricultural research on farming systems; soil and water management; and production of traditional cereals, legumes, vegetables, fruits, rice and cotton, as well as animal husbandry. Among the achievements during this period were: development and adaptation of improved and disease-resistant crop varieties and preparation of appropriate technical programs for growing of them; improved knowledge of the physical environment and identification of improved water management techniques; development of appropriate farming tools and postharvest processing equipment; studies on farm budgets and production constraints; development of techniques for multiplication of tree plants; creation of an ethno-botanical data bank; and quantification of natural pastures and development of improved rations for intensive sheep production for small holders. 2.24 In 1991 the Government adopted a Structural Adjustment Program to improve the competitiveness of the economy and establish a basis for sustainable development. The actions under this program concerned the fiscal policy, scope of the public sector, reform of the banking sector, reform of tariffs and trade policies and liberalization of prices. Realizing the priority that had to be accorded to the agricultural sector in the new development approach, the Government had prepared already in 1992 a special adjustment program for this sector and obtained for its implementation an adjustment credit from IDA and financial assistance from other development partners (para 1.3). AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT SYSTEM 3.1 Agricultural Technology Support System. The main institutions involved in agricultural technology development in Burkina Faso are the Agricultural Research Institute (INERA) (including the Tropical Agricultural and Foodcrops Research Institute, IRBET, merged with INERA in 1997), universities and the network of Pre-extension Experimentation Stations (PAPEMs). INERA and the new IRSAT have a critical role in applied research, benefiting from the basic research done by the international research institutes, advanced research agencies in developed countries and, to a limited extent, the universities. For purposes of farming system research and coordination, the country is divided into five agro-ecological zones, each serviced by one of INERA's Regional Stations that have responsibility for zone-specific adaptive research and, to a certain extent, for conveying the findings to the extension and farming community. Within each zone the PAPEMs conduct adaptive research and help disseminate research results to smallholder farmers. PAPEMs are not directly linked to INERA but are part of the agricultural extension structure. However, collaboration between the PAPEMs and the research stations is active. 3.2 Thus, there are several tiers of technology development and dissemination: (a) on-farm applied research (OFR) using the farming systems teams of INERA's regional stations; (b) on-farm adaptive research (OFAR) by the PAPEMs and other state-level agencies; and (c) technology dissemination through the unified extension system using the Training and Visit (T&V) methodology of extension management. 3.3 On-Farm Applied Research (Researcher-managed Adaptive Research). Applied research is conducted by the farming system research and natural resource management teams of INERA's regional research stations to develop appropriate technologies. This type of research involves researcher-managed experiments to develop new and improved technologies under various agro-ecological conditions. The purpose for research and extension teams is to learn how farmers react to introduced changes, to what extent the introductions are accepted, modified, or rejected, and why farmers respond to new technologies the way they do. Specific experiments are carried out at research farms, PAPEM farms or on farmers' fields with as much control of the variables as possible. Combining the understanding of the farming systems practiced by farmers, the background information on technology development and interaction with farmers, the researcher teams propose improvements to increase the productivity and profitability of the farming systems. 3.4 On-Farm Adaptive Research (OFAR). OFAR serves as the bridge between the development and extension of new technologies. It is used by the extension system and its Regional Centres for Agro- pastoral Promotion (CRPAs) as the first stage in the technology dissemination process. The technologies generated from the OFAR recommendations are further tested. Farmers fully participate in these tests, so that they can adapt them to specific farming situations based on farmers' resource base, technical abilities, cropping and livestock patterns and farm/household conditions. The OFAR methodology ensures the acceleration of the adoption of proven technologies; at the same time, it helps to better prepare extension
 12 staff on technologies they promote during the mass diffusion stage. It entails more work on farmers' fields, generally utilizing less expensive staff. It also requires increased expenditures in vehicle purchase and maintenance, field equipment, elementary agricultural mechanization, multiplication of improved planting, livestock and fisheries materials as well as simple tools for the trials, daily allowances and incentives. Due to resource constraints, most of the CRPAs (presently DRARAs) are yet to implement the OFAR approach. 3.5 Technology Dissemination. The dissemination of most agricultural technologies to small-scale farmers takes place through the Training and Visit System (T&V). It is the responsibility of the DRARAs under the reorganized and unified extension service. The entire country is currently using the T&V extension management system, with about 1,000 Base Extension Agents (CAPs) working at the village levels with CAP-to-farmer ratios typically ranging between 1:800 and 1: 1,200. In each zone of the DRARA, extension staff have delineated the farming areas into contiguous operational units (circles). Within these circles, the extension agent works with selected groups of farmers. These farmers are the "'official" contact group representing the rest of the farmers in the community. The contact groups also provide the upward linkage from farmers to extension and research. The CAPs, supervised by 145 Zonal Extension Supervisors, visit the contact groups and other farmers in the sub-circle at regular fortnightly intervals. During the visits, the CAPs teach the farmers a maximum of three to four carefully chosen production recommendations that they have learned at Fortnightly Training Sessions (FNTSs). Thus, under the unified extension approach, a single field-level extension agent, supervised by a zonal officer and backed by 150 Technical Specialists (TSs) specialized in subject matters typical for the region, is the farmers' principal contact for the dissemination of all agricultural technologies. There is a team of 4 to 6 TSs in each Province. 3.6 The placement of TSs within the DRARAs helps bridge the gap between the generation of technologies by researchers and the broad-scale diffusion of improved technologies by extension staff. The TSs are specialists in such fields as agronomy, agroforestry, plant protection, livestock, farm management, fisheries, water management and farm implements (agricultural mechanization). Because the CAPs are generalists, TSs are more cost-effective, if used for training CAPs, than if they were used as individual specialists working at the farmer level. Unification of extension is of critical importance given that, in a large majority of farms, livestock, agro-forestry and crop production and processing are integrated into a single farming system at the farm level. Exceptions are the nomadic pastoral and the intensive peri-urban livestock production systems which have specialized information needs. In addition, the front-line staff of the livestock service handles still a combination of control and advisory functions. It appears that the control functions take a large portion of the staff's time, thus interfering with the relationship of trust that needs to exist between the extension agent and his client farmers. FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 7.1 In Burkina Faso, determination of project benefits resulting from an agricultural services project must include agricultural and livestock activities performed by smallholders, who represent more than 90 percent of the farmers. In the analysis prepared for this project, the agricultural component included an estimation of farm budgets by agroecological zones and standard types of farms, and an assessment of overall benefits by aggregating farm budgets, according to assumptions made by the mission on prospective adoption rates. The livestock component included an estimation of herd and flock budgets by standard type and an assessment of overall benefits by aggregating herd budgets, according to assumptions made by the mission on the prospective adoption rates by cattle and sheep breeders. A. Farm-level Analysis 7.2 Farm/herd models. Primary project beneficiaries would be small farmers currently practicing low-input, low-output technologies in farming systems. Because cropping systems vary considerably within the four selected agroecological zones, it was assumed that main project benefits would accrue from incremental production resulting from adoption of the improved varieties and associated cultural practices by farmers, along with better livestock health, breeding, feeding and management. To analyze the financial and economic benefits, six different farm models were prepared, one for each agroclimatic zone and two more general models. For livestock, four typical models were used in the analysis (Annex 4, Appendices A and B). 7.3 Determination of benefits and costs. A matrix in Annex 4, Appendix A, indicates, by type of farm, the technical packages and levels of productivity that were used to assess benefits from target farms and to estimate impact in each agroecological zone. The yield increases were projected to vary from 14 percent to 41 percent (depending on the region and the crop), and to be achieved over four years only by the adopting farmers. Three types of cattle herds and one type of flock of sheep have been used for the economic model. The first corresponds to a transhumant cattle herd of 45 heads located in the Sahel. The two other types correspond to relatively sedentary cattle herds located throughout Burkina Faso, which are integrated with cropping activities through the use of ox-drawn cultivation and organic manure. 7.4 Inputs and financial prices. For cropping activities, the major inputs used in production are labor, fertilizer, farm chemicals and improved seeds. Labor, the single most important component of crop production costs in Burkina Faso, accounts for about 60 to 80 percent of total input costs. Fertilizer use in Burkina Faso is extremely low at 7.5 kg/ha. Prices for these inputs are set by the government (subsidies were suppressed in 1996, along with an important increase in the farmgate price of cotton). Other inputs of increasing importance in food crop production are improved seeds and agrochemicals for seed treatment. 7.5 Output markets and financial prices. The major constraints to efficient marketing of agricultural outputs are a poor distribution network, which leads to wide disparity between farmgate and retail market prices and seasonal price fluctuations; inadequate low-cost storage at the farm level; and inadequate processing capacity at the village level. The project includes research and extension activities to alleviate a part of these constraints, in particular through farmer organizations. As demand for domestically produced crops is high, the above project activities would facilitate the market absorption of the increased production to be generated under the project.
 31 7.6 Farm and Herd Financial Budgets. For the agricultural component, the farm-level returns were estimated on the basis of "with project" and "without project" situations. Six models were reviewed in the crop production situations and four for the livestock component. All farm budgets showed a significant increase of returns to farm family; a major part of this increase can be attributed to project interventions (Annex 4, Appendix A). The benefit/cost ratios (B:C ratios) for the different crop budgets with the project varied from to 1.06 to 1.95, as against the B:C ratios without the project of 0.92 to 1.91. The ratios were calculated after allowing the present farm salaries to be paid for the family labor in the without-project situation, and increased salaries for the with-the-project situation. The best B:C ratio would be possible to reach by cultivating valley-bottom rice (anywhere in the country), followed by the farm model using oxen power in the West. The weakest ratio would be reached in the Sahel area with or without the project, the former being, however, higher. 7.7 Moreover, the budgets that were calculated for herds showed significant increases in returns to breeders, mainly because of project interventions (Annex 4, Appendix B). For instance, in the year 10 after the project start, the herds of the adopting owners would have grown up to 45 percent more (depending on the type of the herd) in the with-project case than without. The incremental benefit resulting from the value of milk, meat, hides and manure would be 41 percent to 51 percent higher in the with-project case. B. Project-Level Economic Analysis 7.8 Approach and assumptions (Implementation Manual, Annex 4). Economic benefits from the project were determined on the basis of the following assumptions: (a) a project life of 20 years, 12 commencing with a one-year lag for the accrual of benefits; (b) an investment period of six years, including the total costs of the research, agricultural service and farner organization components, but excluding the costs of the support to the restructuring of AGRI-RA; (c) a without-project situation generally increasing slightly because of inputs remaining from the predecessor project and informal transfer of technology through other than project channels ( including herds that were assumed to grow in both cases); (d) all prices of outputs and inputs expressed in 1996 constant economic values; and (e) an opportunity cost of capital of 12 percent. For internationally traded commodities such as rice and cotton, import parity farm-gate prices were used. 7.9 The number of typical farms or herd owners that would adopt technical farm or livestock packages and benefit from the full impact of this adoption was estimated by the mission on the basis of the adoption rates reported under the ongoing project (PRSAP I) by the Monitoring and Evaluation Unit of the DVA of AGRI-RA. The adoption rates used in the base case of the present economic model are on average 40 percent higher than the adoption rates reported for Phase I; they vary from 10 to 15 percent of the total number of existing farms according to the ecological zone and the type of farm. In the farm models, a farm that adopts the proposed technical package in project year (PY) n is supposed to reach the yield objectives in year n+4. For each PY, one sixth of the total target standard farms (total target is 10 to 15 percent of the existing farms) are assumed to adopt the proposed technical package. Every five years the benefits are reduced by 30 percent to take into account periodical drought. 2 / The economic analysis was computed at appraisal for a six-year project period. Because this project is a second phase of a longer term-program, the computation period was not changed at post-appraisal when the project period was reduced to four years.
 32 7.10 Project costs in the economic analysis. The costs used in the economic analysis of the project contain incremental costs of investment and recurrent costs, including physical contingencies, for both the research and agricultural services component. Cost of support to the restructuring of AGRI-RA is excluded from the economic analysis. The base case takes into account only costs of staff under contract to be financed by the proposed IDA Credit (which represents a small proportion of the total staffing costs necessary to implement the project). 7.11 Economic rate of return and net present value. Based on the foregoing assumptions, the economic rate of return calculated for NASDP II is estimated at 39 percent with a net present value (NPV) of CFAF 58 billions at an opportunity cost of investment capital (OCIR) of 12 percent. 7.12 The costs of the project's main components can also be expressed as percentage of agricultural GDP. For agricultural research, the costs are about 0.5 percent of the agricultural GDP and for agricultural extension a little less. In relation to public expenditure, the demand of counterpart funds for the implementation of the project, about US$1.5 million equivalent per year, would equal about 2.1 percent of the 1997 government budget for all projects. 7.13 Sensitivity analysis. The following factors were determined as likely to affect project viability: decrease in assumed incremental benefits linked to lower yields and/or lower adoption rates; increase in costs of rural labor; increase in project costs; and delayed project impact and benefits. For a given percentage of variation from the base case of one given variable, the corresponding ERR was computed (Annex 4, Appendix C). The ERR is not very sensitive to changes in individual variables. For instance, a 60 percent reduction in the projected incremental farm and livestock output, or both combined, would still give an estimated ERR of 23 percent, 33 percent, and 19 percent, respectively. A 100 percent increase in the cost of labor, a 20 percent increase in total project costs, and a two-year delay in project implementation would still allow an ERR at 30 percent, 31 percent and 27 percent, respectively. The switching value analysis, using 12 percent opportunity cost of capital, would allow the project costs to increase by 350 percent before the project net present value (NPV) would be equal to zero. VIII. BENEFITS, JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. Benefits and Justification 8.1 Project benefits. The programs supported by the project are expected to help increase agricultural productivity and develop sustainable production systems for rainfed crops, irrigated crops and livestock production for the domestic market and for export. These form a set of direct quantifiable benefits used in the financial and economic analysis (Chapter 7). Direct but non-quantified benefits under the proposed project are: improved nutritional status of rural households through diversification of cropping systems and increase of milk and meat consumption; increased employment; human resource development, including improved literacy and numeracy; and improved productivity of on rural women through targeting part of the extension information to women farmers. Indirect project benefits, also not quantified in this analysis, derive from enhancing of food security in poor rural households, allowing subsistence producers to replenish stocks of food and seeds, which are usually reduced or depleted during the lean season. The project would also promote somewhat increased use of fertilizer, leading to improved soils to better sustain smallholder farming activities, as well as environmentally friendly farming practices. 8.2 Farmers' access to inputs, availability of credit, and post-harvest technologies are expected to improve during the project period. Institution building under the project would improve the efficiency
 33 and effectiveness of both the public agricultural services and farmer organizations. In liaison with the Agriculture SECAL, the public agricultural services would be restructured to focus on appropriate research and extension and become more cost-efficient. By improving the managerial capacity and economic power of farmer organizations, the program would contribute to improved welfare of farmers and rural poor, and to increase added value of agricultural products. The project would also promote the rural private sector by creating an enabling environment for farmer organizations and local traders to take on roles as marketers of inputs, a role that would be transferred to them from the CRPAs. 8.3. Environmental issues. The main potential environmental issue concerns the possibility of longer-term farm land degradation resulting from the adoption of more intensive but not sustainable production systems. However, the agricultural research, extension, and on-farm adaptation programs would emphasize sustainable land and water resource management and agroforestry as part of the technology packages to be promoted to farmers. The project would be closely linked with the Natural Resources Management Project and would extend the technology developed under that project to more numerous farm communities. Moreover, adoption of better farming techniques on farmed land would reduce the necessity of expanding agriculture into more marginal lands. The project would not involve any resettlement of people or financing of agrochemicals. The proposed project is designed to promote environmentally sustainable agriculture. At initial project identification and in line with general regional policy regarding agricultural services projects, this project was classified as Category C. However, preappraisal review determined that it should be classified as Category B. Consequently, the Government will need to carry out a targeted environmental analysis according to Bank guidelines. At the time of negotiations, the consultants for environmental analysis had been invited to make proposals for the assignment. Completion of this study would be a condition of effectiveness of the project. (Environmental effects are also discussed in Annex VI of the Project Implementation Manual.) 8.4 Program Objectives and Poverty Categories. The Poverty Profile 1996 shows that the incidence of poverty is 52 percent in subsistence agriculture, substantially higher than for the population in general (35 percent). Rural areas must therefore become the focal point of public service delivery and efforts to improve access to financial resources. The smallholder farmers, including women, being the main target group of this project, the main program objectives would be the alleviation of rural poverty and farmer empowerment. The applicable Targeted Intervention Categories are expected to be Raising Productivity and Poverty Alleviation. 8.5 Participatory Approach. Project preparation relied mainly on documents prepared by the implementing agencies and experience gained over the last 6 to 7 years in implementing a similar project in Burkina Faso. Project preparation work was done entirely by staff of the two ministries involved in the project. Early client consultation started in 1995, at which time AGRI-RA began a process of preparing a participatory action plan, with an adequate focus on women, as well as obtaining the viewpoints of the involved agencies, particularly smallholder farmers and their organizations. Work performed by consultants under this assignment was extensively discussed at regional and national workshops and conferences before preappraisal. On the side of agricultural research, the research institutes have been year involving farmer organizations in their work for a year or two by making contracts on research assignments of direct interest to the members of these organizations. In the future, farmers' participation in the Agricultural Services Program, including agricultural research, will be strengthened by enhancing the capacity of farmers' organizations to participate in planning, implementation and evaluation at different levels, including workshops on a strategy for agricultural services, regional technology reviews, diagnosis at village and farm levels, program evaluations and impact assessments. The participatory approach will be based on methodology and experience already
 34 well established for developing village land management plans (gestion des terroirs). The principle of participatory approach has been agreed with the Government at the initial stage of preparation. B. Risks 8.6 Besides the climatic uncertainties, the main project risks--impossible to quantify--are: (a) potential reversal of sound economic policies, including implementation of the proposed restructuring of AGRI-RA; (b) inadequate counterpart funding; and (c) constraints to achieving better efficiency of extension services, including potential lack of inputs. The approach used in this report was to analyze the factors involved, assess their impact on project outcomes, establish a subjective probability of their likely occurrence based on country information and field knowledge, and propose mitigating measures that can be taken by (he Borrower (Implementation Manual, Annex 4, Appendix C). 8.7 According to this analysis, the high-risk factors for project implementation appear to be the potential lack of counterpart funding l and less-than-needed efficiency of the project institutions. These have been taken into account in designing the project as follows: - Agricultural policies and restructuring of AGRI-R4. Many of the sector issues that often hinder agricultural development are unlikely to affect this project. Most of these issues began to be addressed under the Agricultural Adjustment Credit program (SECAL I) and they should be resolved during the Second National Agricultural Adjustment Credit program (SECAL II). They include improvement in the performance of public-sector institutions supporting agricultural development and competitiveness of key subsectors (rice, sugar, cotton and livestock). These improvements, if implemented, would support the effect of the investments under this project. To reduce the risk of implementation failure or delay, the project would provide funds to facilitate the restructuring of AGRI-RA and would include conditionalities to ensure that the deadlines are met. - Counterpartfunds. Delayed provision of counterpart funds, a problem experienced in the past, would be reduced by adapting the project scope and the share of recurrent costs to be financed by the Borrower to the Borrower's financial capacity, and seeking a relatively high level of IDA financing as requested by the Government. Increasing assistance from other multilateral and bilateral donors, usually in the form of grants, is also expected to facilitate achievement of project objectives. - The efficiency of the extension services. Inefficiencies could result from a possible lack of adapted technologies and lower-than-projected adoption rates by producers. These inefficiencies would be mitigated by implementing regional technology reviews, improving linkages between research and extension, developing participatory approaches and getting farmer organizations involved in planning and deciding on the type and quality of agricultural services and establishing priorities and adapting the pace of program implementation. 13/ The Government has provided the requested counterpart funds under the predecessor projects during the recent years, but the amounts have been smaller that during the proposed project.

All goods and services financed under the IDA Credit would be procured in accordance with IDA guidelines of goods, works and services (Guidelines: Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits, January 1995 and as revised in January and August 1996 (Procurement Guidelines) and Guidelines: Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by World Bank as Executing Agency, January 1997 (Consultant Guidelines). Contracts to supply goods and equipment, vehicles, and civil engineering services for the project would be put up for bid and awarded by the project implementation units (Project Coordination Unit for AGRI-RA, and INERA and IRSAT for MESSRS), or, if above their approval limits, by the authorized bodies in the Government system (the respective Ministry and the National Procurement Office). Preference for domestically manufactured goods in ICB will apply in accordance with World bank Guidelines. Contracts for civil works 2 All bidding documents and contracts in this category except small rehabilitationworks and works for the pilot component "small rural infrastructures"valued at less than US$50,000 each, would be procured through NCB and reviewed by IDA. Rehabilitationand constructionworks would usually be grouped into regional lots to enable local small and medium-size enterprises to participate in the bidding, although overseas firms and firms from elsewhere in the country may also bid. Documentation acceptable to IDA would be required. Contracts for the pilot components,estimated to cost less than US$30,000 equivalent, could be made by using "communityparticipation"method, followingproceduresstated in the Implementation Manual, acceptable to IDA, with an aggregate amount not exceeding US$3 million equivalent. Contracts for vehicles. goods and equipment 3. Contracts for vehicles, goods and equipmentwould be grouped by lots. All lots valued at over US$200,000 would be procured through International Competitive Bidding (ICB) procedure based on use of the World Bank model documentation. National Competitive Bidding (NCB) procedures acceptable to IDA could be used for contracts in the range of US$50,000 to US$200,000. IDA's prior approval of the bidding documents and contract would be required for ICB and NCB procurement. Contracts under US$50,000 to purchase vehicles and small equipment, which should not exceed a total of US$2 million during the project, may be awarded on the basis of local or international shopping, provided at least three competent competitorsare invited to bid. The implementation units would be requested to prepare a computer-based system to monitor that the aggregate amounts agreed upon will not be exceeded (see para 5).

Consultant services would be procured from local or, on a short-term basis, from internationalfirms. The consultantswould be selected accordingto IDA guidelines (January 1997) and the provisions of the respective Schedule in the Development Credit Agreement (DCA). Their contracts would be based on terms of reference approved by IDA, Except in specific cases approved by IDA, contracts in this category could be awarded on the basis of shopping, provided that at least three competent firms or consultants are approached. The details of the arrangements would be as follows: 4.1 Ouality- and Cost-based Selection. Except as otherwise provided in paragraph 4.3, consultants' services shall be procured under contracts awarded in accordance with the provisions of Section II of the Consultant Guidelines, paragraph 3 of Appendix I thereto, Appendix 2 thereto, and the provisions of paragraphs 3.13 through 3.18 thereof applicable to quality- and cost-based selection of consultants. 4.2. The following provisions shall apply to consultants' services to be procured under contracts awarded in accordance with the provisions of the preceding paragraph. The short list of consultants for services for the Project, estimated to cost less than $100,000 equivalent per contract, may comprise entirely national consultants in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 2.7 of the Consultant Guidelines. 4.3 Other Procedures for the Selection of Consultants: (a) Selection Under a Fixed Budget: Services for small contracts estimated to cost less than $50,000 equivalent per contract, related to simple engineering designs and mapping works under Parts A and D of the Project (see DCA) may be procured under contracts awarded in accordance with the provisions of paragraphs 3.1 and 3.5 of the Consultant Guidelines; (b) Selection Based on Consultants' Qualifications: Services for contracts to be implemented technical or professional support or other contracts where the need for preparing and evaluating a competitive proposal is not justified, under Parts A, B, and E of the Project (see DCA), estimated to cost less than $20,000 equivalent per contract for individual consultants and $50,000 equivalent per contract for consulting firns, may be procured under contracts awarded in accordance with the provisions of paragraphs 3.1 and 3.7 of the Consultant Guidelines. doc.abstracts: The Second National Agricultural Services Development Project aims to: (i) support long-term agricultural production; (ii) increase agricultural and livestock productivity and farmers' revenues; (iii) improve natural resource management and promote sustainable production systems; (iv) help the Government implement an improved animal health system, largely based on private veterinary services; and (v) promote and empower, on a pilot basis, representative farmers' organizations. The project includes the following five main components: 1) agricultural research; 2) agricultural extension (rainfed and irrigated crops, livestock, natural resource management); 3) animal health and pastoralist promotion; 4) pilot programs consisting of: (a) promotion of farmer organizations; and (b) a program for small rural infrastructures to study the processes and feasibility of financing village-level operations intended for communal usage; and 5) restructuring of agricultural services.
